titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the William Anthony Papers,1955-2013 (Bulk 1976-2013) MSS.081
titlestmt.author: Laura Newsome, 2011. Accretions processed by Nicholas Martin, 2014.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-06-27 18:19:28 -0400.

change.item: Record updated by Rachel Searcy to reflect 2022 accretion

physdesc.extent: in 2 record cartons and 1 folder in shared housing

did.abstract: William Anthony (1934-2022) was an American painter, illustrator, and graphic artist working in satire. This William Anthony Papers primarily contain facsimiles of Anthony's work, documenting his artistic career from 1976 though 2004. There are also some original artworks, photographs of Anthony, and other personal materials.
did.physloc: Materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please request materials at least two business days prior to your research visit to coordinate access.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: William Anthony (1934-2022) was an American painter, illustrator, and graphic artist working in satire. Anthony was born in Ft. Monmouth, New Jersey in 1934, and grew up in Washington State. He graduated from Yale in 1958, majoring in history and taking art courses, including Josef Albers's drawing course. Shortly after graduation he moved to the San Francisco Bay Area where he studied briefly at art schools.

Anthony taught figure drawing at a commercial art school in San Francisco in 1962. This experience resulted in a his first book, A New Approach to Figure Drawing, 1965, (Crown, NY, and Odhams, 1967, London). His other books, all of satirical drawings, include Bible Stories, 1978, (The Jargon Society, Winston-Salem), Bill Anthony's Greatest Hits, (1988, The Jargon Society), and War Is Swell, 2000, (Smart Art Press, Santa Monica).
His drawings have been commissioned for Artforum, The Paris Review, Art In America, and by Andy Warhol for his magazine Interview.
The Museum of Modern Art, the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Whitney Museum, the Guggenheim Museum, the Brooklyn Museum and 20 other museums include Anthony's work in their collections.
Anthony lived in New York since 1964 and passed away in 2022.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection primarily contains facsimiles of Anthony's work, documenting his artistic career from 1976 though 2022. There are also some original artworks, photographs of Anthony, and other personal materials.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection was arranged and described by the donor. Minor changes have been made by the archivist to improve accessibility.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Materials are open without restrictions. Please contact the Fales Library and Special Collections, fales.library@nyu.edu, 212-998-2596.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: This collection is protected by copyright and/or related rights. You are free to use materials in the collection in any way that is permitted by the copyright and related rights legislation that applies to your use. For other uses you need to obtain permission from the rights-holder(s).

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The William Anthony Papers were donated to NYU's Fales Library and Special Collections by William Anthony in 1996, 2009 and 2013. In 2022, an accretion was donated by the estate of William Anthony; the accession number associated with this accretion is 2023.009.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p:
Published citations should take the following form:
Identification of item, date (if known); The William Anthony Papers; MSS 081; box number; folder number; Fales Library and Special Collections, New York University Libraries.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Decisions concerning the arrangement, description, and physical interventions taken on this collection prior to 2023 have not been recorded. In February 2023, an accretion was rehoused in an archival folder and box, and intellectually integrated into the collection as its own series in keeping with the collection's existing arrangement structure.
